          “Oh, Yoongi,” the voice said slowly, the hand stilling on his back.  Another shudder, and the hand started to move away.  “Okay, let’s lay you back down.  Can you do that—”

          “Please,” Yoongi pleaded, fumbling to grab onto something and falling into the voice’s chest.  It, he, was so warm, warm and welcoming, and Yoongi wanted to stay there forever. “Please don’t leave me again.  I-I can’t.”

          “O-okay,” the voice said uneasily.  “Okay, I-I’m here.  Just-just lie down, again?  Here we go.”

          Yoongi let himself be guided, led, moved because it’s what he needed.  He needed just one good dream, just one comforting thought.  He needed the hand brushing through his hair and the arm holding him close.  He needed the chest to sob into, the warm skin to welcome him back even after he had been away for so long.  He needed that voice to tell him he was going to be alright, that they were going to be alright, that everything was going to be alright.

          “Okay, okay,” it said, which was almost good enough. It almost sounded like him.  It was almost too good.  It was the best fever dream he could remember having, and even if he knew it was a dream, the acknowledgement only made him calmer and more relaxed like he actually believed everything was going to be alright.

A/N: AH!!!

I always have to have someone sick in a bathtub in my stories, apparently.

What’s up with those dreams???  Dang.
trail.content:
Summary:  Yoongi loves photography. Taehyung loves photography. Yoongi likes eating good food and dogs and holding hands. Taehyung likes holding hands and dogs and eating good food.  Yoongi does not, dear God, like kids.  Taehyung, thank God, loves kids. But when his brother dies, it’s Yoongi who suddenly has to look after four-year-old Jimin and three-year-old Jungkook.

A/N:  You guessed it!  It’s trope time!

The Korean version of 911 (I’m in the U.S.) is 119. It’s backwards!  That’s easy to remember.  (There’s also 116, apparently).

The italics in this story are past conversations or thoughts.

More notes at the end.

WC: 6,803

Warnings: Some bad words. People throwing up, ew.  Reference of abuse / physical violence.

Masterlist

13. Hoseok and Jimin “Made Out”

14. Fever Dreams

           Yoongi was, honestly, impressed and surprised and a little bit proud of himself for making it so long before it happened.  He’s always been introverted, so to have gone from living alone and having every minute to himself if he so wished to suddenly never being alone even when he was just trying to go to the bathroom was a difficult whirlwind to adjust to.  

          He has never been one to yell—he can remember the three times he has yelled at someone in his adult life exactly as if they just happened yesterday: one, when he finally resorted to raising his voice to convince his parents he was serious about dropping out of school; two, when he was so, incredibly, will-never-be-that-badly-drunk-again and thought he had lost his brother so he went around screaming his head off in a crowded street in the middle of the night like an absolute lunatic; and three, when he was so embarrassed after confessing to Namjoon that he reacted by trying to get him to leave him alone, but no amount of yelling would ever make Namjoon stop being his friend, so he had never screamed at him again.  He had always leaned toward melting down, imploding, instead of exploding, tended to shut down and shut people out instead of complaining and drawing attention to himself.

          He also was used to pressing everything down and holding everything in, keeping everything to himself instead of reaching out to others even if all he wanted was someone to come alongside and help him. That’s why, every time he has ever had a bad meltdown or had gotten sick, it always hit him alarmingly quickly, like a freight train, like a thief in the night.  The lack of warning made it worse because that was what made him feel completely out of control, helpless and vulnerable.  Weak and pathetic.

          He could hear the boys waking up.  Their voices sounded muffled and distant, like they were underwater, and some irrational fear that they were drowning in the bathtub is what made him sit up, immediately regretting his decision as he groaned and grabbed his head to keep the world from turning upside down.

          “He’s awa’e!” Jungkook shouted, his continual need to be right in Yoongi’s face, to invade his space, extremely frustrating for some reason this morning.  With his eyes squinted shut, all of the skin on his face feeling pulled tight and yet so loose it might be melting off his skull, Yoongi reached out blindly and tried to move the boy away from him as gently as possible.  The movement, however, caused his stomach to lurch, and with a curse, a thud, another curse, Jimin screaming a reprimand at him, and Jungkook letting out a little breath as he collided with something, Yoongi tumbled off of the bed, only prying his eyes open enough to stumble into the bathroom, slamming the door behind him.

          Yoongi couldn’t recall the last time he threw up. He could remember it; he knew it was some dumb decision when he was trying to pretend he didn’t care about anything while really all he wanted in the world was his parent’s approval and his brother’s love and Namjoon’s support and his work to have purpose and success because he was working his ass off even though no one seemed to care or notice, and he knew he didn’t like getting that drunk again and stuck to wine or whiskey now to avoid going overboard, but he had forgotten how awful it was.  

          How much it absolutely wracked his small frame and made tears prickle in his eyes involuntarily.  How much it stung and lingered even after he brushed his teeth multiple times. How it made his entire body shake and break into a sweat.  How, for a split second, it always made him feel like he was actually dying.  How, of all of the gross things he had had to deal with in the past few weeks—mainly, urine—it was by far his least favorite thing to clean up, and even though he needed to wipe down the toilet and scrub the floor and brush his teeth for the third time, he found himself slinking back to the ground, sweating and breathing heavily, groaning as he heard the boys pounding on the door, Jimin’s screams louder than anything at all.  

          His arms were too weak to reach the handle, and if his throat didn’t feel like he had swallowed a slug covered in poison meant to burn his esophagus, he would have told the boys to just come in, but he closed his eyes instead, barely registering how Jimin’s screams and the pounding stopped as their little feet padded away.

          Tae isn’t exactly sure why Eunnie had sent him five pictures of his neighbor at the daycare taking pictures of kids with the message “Look what you missed out on.”  The embarrassment had hit him first mixed with regret and annoyance at himself. He remembered Eunnie mentioning having him come and take pictures.  He knew Jin had mentioned it at least once or twice, too.  

          But Eunnie, even though she has grown annoyed with him before and vocally shared her frustration with Jin or straight up to him, would never gloat or make fun of him so blatantly.  So it took him a second to register who was in the picture. Her text must have meant that he missed out on seeing Yoongi, then, and it took him several steps of staring at his phone with a frown before he figured out what she could mean.

          With a groan, he promised himself to stop telling everything to Jin even after the guy had promised he wouldn’t tell anyone else. Tae kept forgetting that that rule didn’t seem to apply to his wife.  Something gross about being one flesh or “she’s my everything” or “she can tell when I’m hiding something, so to protect my beautiful face I never do so.”

          He may have, in passing, said something about Yoongi to Jin at some point.  He may have mentioned Yoongi getting jealous that one day he had seen Jin at his place. Jin may have laughed at him.  Tae may have gotten fussy and grumbled about how he wasn’t helping.  He may have said something about how much he liked his tattoos and how distracting seeing Yoongi shirtless while he hovered over him on his couch had been.  He may have pretended to ignore the smirk and eyebrow raise Jin had given him.

          Groaning again at how careless he had been, Tae kept looking at the pictures of Yoongi as he climbed the steps to his apartment. Despite how easily distracted and scatterbrained Tae was, he could concentrate when he needed to.  And he often stared at people, not in a creepy way, except they often thought so if they were strangers and noticed him doing it, but because he considered them walking pieces of art, and art was meant to be admired.  He loved looking from afar and up close, because perspective can change everything. He once told Jin that he never felt like he really knew a person until he had seen them in a multitude of places. He meant that people are different at home and at work, often, so to truly know them you have to observe them in both places.  Jin had mentioned something perverted about how many people Tae wanted to see in bed, too, and while Tae had not responded, he wasn’t exactly wrong.  To see someone happy and sad, stressed and angry, tired and sick, at their best and at their worst, is the only way to truly know someone. He complained often to Jin, each time a boyfriend or potential date left him, that they never stuck around long enough to see him in all areas.  Jin had made another crude joke, but Tae knew he was just trying to lighten the mood.  

          Looking at Yoongi’s pictures, Tae simply felt like he was seeing him in a different light.  He had seen the man crying, had seen him exhausted and at his last rope, and anyone else might just assume that that was all the man had to offer. Frowns and baggy eyes and hurried conversations because he had to get back to his kids.  Tae had seen the man as a dad, or, an uncle, a care giver. But he hadn’t seen him at work. He hadn’t seen him really smile yet, he didn’t think.  A few polite grins or ones of relief, sure, but each of those told a different story. The Yoongi he saw on his small phone screen told him something more than he had ever gleaned from seeing the man in person.  He was clearly passionate.  He concentrated and worked hard.  But he felt overwhelmed, probably by the kids, if Tae remembered correctly what Yoongi had said about how much he didn’t like to photograph people, and looked exhausted.  The exhaustion wasn’t like what Tae had seen before, though, and the frown on Yoongi’s face wasn’t one of anger.  The man looked like he was about to fall apart even with a camera half-hiding his face, and it was that look that Tae couldn’t look away from.

          He knew that Yoongi was older than him, but something in the man’s face and body posture, the way he had squatted down to be at eye-level with each kid, made him look much younger.  Smaller, too, but Tae already knew the man was shorter than him. He couldn’t see any of his tattoos, the man’s sleeves covering them up, but he was imaging them.  Art on art, is what they were.  They made Yoongi look even more beautiful, or he made them stand out more.  Tae wasn’t sure which was enhancing the other.  All he knew was Eunnie was right.  He had missed out on not only another job, but also on seeing Yoongi at work, and as he scaled the top of the stairs, he paused by the guy’s door, wondering how much his neighbor would hate him for dropping in unannounced.  He could always go home and text him to make it look more planned, but several sounds made him stop and frown at the blue door before he could.

          While he had really only heard Jungkook and Jimin crying once before, he didn’t think he would ever forget what their cries sounded like.  They seemed to have struck his heart deep enough that even the quiet sound of them dug into his flesh even more, the pain spreading and panic welling.  Without waiting to text or give Yoongi any other sort of warning, he rose his fist to pound on the door.  He wanted to think that the guy hadn’t lost it in the middle of the day.  He hoped there was more to him, more good, never more bad, behind the exterior he had. Tae hoped he hadn’t misjudged him. He didn’t have the best track record when it came to trusting men in his life, or so Jin had told him over and over again.  But Yoongi seemed different.  Or Tae wanted him to be.  Yoongi was—

          “Yoongi?” Tae said, pounding on the door again.  He heard someone crying and someone else mumbling, the sounds too low to the ground and high-pitched to be a grown man. “Jimin?  Jungkook?”

          “Tae-tae?” Jimin said through the door, and Tae sighed in relief, his fist leaving the door to curl around the doorknob.

          “I’m coming in, okay?”  Not waiting for an answer, and really hoping Yoongi wasn’t on the other side of the door ready to knife someone for breaking in, Tae pushed the door open, meeting a little resistance that he realized was the cowering bodies of two small boys, both who started to grab at his pants and gasp a little as they both started to rattle on.  Tae caught “Yoo-yoo” and “bathroom” enough between the pair of them, their words frantic and jumbled, to know where he needed to go, so making sure he closed the door and placed what he hoped was a soothing hand on both of the boys’ shoulders, he trotted down the short hallway to where the bathroom must be.

          “Yoongi?” he called before trying the door.  He kept one hand behind him to keep the boys back despite how much they were crowding around him, afraid of what he might find.  After finding his own grandma collapsed in her bedroom floor when he was ten, he had been aware of how scarring the sight of someone you love who is in charge of taking care of you looking seemingly dead can be for a child.  

          “Yoongi?” he said again, closing the door behind him before the boys could slip in, ignoring how Jimin started yelling again, his and Jungkook’s feet kicking at the door.  Compared to Tae, Yoongi was pale.  Tae had noticed that when he first became aware of the man.  His skin looked like porcelain, and right now he looked fragile enough to break if touched, but Tae dropped to the floor immediately, placing his hand on the man’s sweaty brow and hissing at how warm he felt.

          “Yoongi?” he said again, his nose wrinkling at how smelly the small room was.  Trying to be gentle, he peeled up one of Yoongi’s eyelids to see his pupils wide. The man groaned a bit, enough of a sign for Tae to know he was at least not dead, and he felt his heart calm immediately.  Still, he looked terrible, and Tae’s brain worked quickly, trying to remember the steps to take.  One time when Hoseok was three he had gotten sick at Tae’s house, and he had gone so pale and clammy so quickly that Tae almost called 119, but Eunnie had walked him through what to do calmly over the phone as she and Jin headed back early.

          “Yoongi?” Tae repeated, not really waiting for the man to reply, just wanting to try to get his attention and inform him of what he was doing so he wouldn’t freak out.  “I need to get you to the bath.  Can you stand?”  Yoongi grunted, and he started to push himself off of the wall and floor at the same time, which Tae knew wasn’t going to work for long, so he took advantage of Yoongi lifting himself just enough to slide an arm under his knees and around his back.  Despite his small size, Yoongi definitely weighed more than Hoseok, and Tae tottered a bit as he stood up, thankful that the wall was so close and Yoongi seemed to be pressing his hand flat against it as they rose.  He only had a few feet to go, anyway, but he moved carefully more than quickly, noting how Yoongi mumbled something before sinking forward a little, his head ducked and causing enough of a shift in balance for Tae to press his own back against the wall to avoid falling over.  Taking a deep breath, he took the last two steps toward the tub, bending down just enough so he could let his arm out from under Yoongi’s legs.

          “Stand up for me, yeah?  Just for a second,” Tae mumbled, his arm still secure around Yoongi’s back as the man complied weakly.  “Okay, good job.  I’ve got you, just stand still for another second.”  Moving carefully, one hand secure on Yoongi’s shoulder and his other arm reaching around to rest securing around his ribs, Tae stepped into the tub behind him.  Yoongi’s back and chest flushed, little blotches of red like drops of paint breaking out all over his skin, and his sweat made Tae’s hands slip a little, but he pressed his fingers harder into the man’s flesh, ignoring the way Yoongi groaned again and finally moved, his hand grabbing Tae’s wrist.  Unsure if he was just holding on or trying to push him away, Tae shushed him a little.  

          “Need you to sit down now, okay?  Gently, slowly.”  Pulling him close as he squatted, Tae let out a breath as Yoongi sat back.  Letting him go once he was secure on his bottom, Tae checked his forehead again, hissing as the man curled up and put his head on his knees.

          “Okay, this is going to be cold, but I need you to just sit here for a second, okay?  I’m going to check on the boys and get you some water.  Will you be alright for a minute?” Tae said, watching as Yoongi barely nodded.  “Okay, okay, then just hold still for me for a little bit.”  Patting Yoongi’s head once, Tae pushed himself up from the side of the tub, fiddling with the handles a little before the shower came on.  The first spray was frigid, and Yoongi let out a small cry, jerking a little.

          “Sorry, sorry.  I know,” Tae mumbled, making it slightly warmer but still keeping it pointed toward the C.  “Just a minute.  Hold on.” Not waiting to see if Yoongi nodded or even agreed, Tae turned to go, stilling the moment he saw the door open, Jimin and Jungkook standing there quietly.  Jungkook had Bun-bun in front of his face, his own eyes barely peeking out past the rabbit’s fur, and Jimin was biting his bottom lip, his cheeks and eyes red.

          “Tae-tae,” the boy said, his lip wobbling the moment he let go of it, “is Yoo-yoo dying?”

          “What?” Tae balked before recovering himself. “No, no.  Don’t worry.  He’s just sick.”  Ushering the boys out, though they both seemed reluctant to go, Tae hurried them into the living room.  “Jimin, can you get me a cup?  Jungkook, we need some clothes for your uncle.  Do you know where those are?”

          “Jung’oo’ ‘an help,” Jungkook nodded, his words mostly muffled by his bunny’s fabric as he headed toward the only dresser in the room. Following him, Tae pulled out what he needed before patting Jungkook’s head in thanks.

          “Will this do?” Jimin said from the kitchen, emerging from one of the cabinets brandishing a plastic cup as if it was the Holy Grail.

          “Perfect,” Tae said honestly, smiling at the boy as he took it.  Filling it up quickly with water, he started to carry the items back to the bathroom. Pausing immediately, however, he turned back to the boys who stopped short, almost bumping into him they were following him so closely.

          “Boys, your uncle is sick, and you need to sleep somewhere else tonight.”

          “Can we stay at yours?” Jimin said hesitantly, but Tae shook his head.

          “We can’t leave your uncle alone, can we?  So we need to make a bed on the floor.  Do you know where the extra blankets are?” Jimin nodded, looking across the room at a closet.

          “I don’t know if I can reach,” he mumbled, sounding infinitely displeased with himself.

          “Okay, okay, don’t hurt yourself.  But if you can, get them out for us, okay?  Just give us a minute in the bathroom, alright?”

          “Bathroom is pri-bit,” Jungkook nodded into Bun-bun’s back again.  Unable to keep a small, endearing smile from his face, Tae nodded back before rushing to the bathroom.  Closing the door again behind him, he closed the toilet seat and put Yoongi’s clothes on it, crouching down by the tub to turn the water off.  By now, Yoongi was shaking, his teeth audibly chattering, and the sight made Tae curse under his breath.

          “Sorry, sorry,” he hissed, lifting Yoongi’s head up and pushing his hair out of the way.  His forehead still felt plenty warm, and he put his hand on the back of Yoongi’s neck where his skin was still wet to lift the cup to his lips.  “Open, please.  I need you to drink this.”  Yoongi grunted at him, drops of water falling from his hair onto his nose and cheeks, but his lips stayed stubbornly pressed together.

          “Yoongi, it’s water.  Just a sip or two, yeah?”  The man seemed to think for a second, so Tae pressed the cup to his lips before removing it. The third time the plastic touched Yoongi’s bottom lip, the man finally sighed and open his mouth enough for Tae to tilt some water in.  Only letting a sip in, he sat it down on the edge of the tub out of the way once they were done.

          “Good job,” he said softly, watching the way Yoongi’s face scrunched up.  Licking his lips a few times, Yoongi turned his head enough that Tae let go of him to stare back as Yoongi finally opened his eyes.  Something in them was akin to the look Tae had seen when he found him outside when he had abandoned the boys inside, and Tae tried not to frown at how much he hated that look on the man’s face, especially since he thought he knew what it was now.

          “Hey,” he said, “the boys are fine.  And you’re going to be.  We need to get you up and changed and back to bed, though, okay?”

          “How?” Yoongi frowned, his voice hoarse and rough. Cocking his head, Tae frowned back.

          “Well, I’m going to help you out, and then we’ll dry you off, and I brought fresh clothes, then—”

          “No, how?” Yoongi asked again, resting his cheek on his knee and sighing again as he shuddered.  Purely instinctually, Tae put a hand on his back, trying to calm him down.

          “I heard the boys crying.  You-you should really lock your door, you know?”

          “Yeah,” Yoongi said, closing his eyes and taking a few deep breaths.  Giving him a moment, Tae took the opportunity to look at the band tattoo on Yoongi’s right bicep.  From afar, he had thought it was just simply black lines, but up close he realized there were tiny numbers sideways alongside the different lines.

          “It’s a camera lens,” he mused out loud, his comment making Yoongi’s eyes open again.

          “Huh?”

          “Your tattoo,” Tae said, moving his hand to run his finger along the band.  Following his movement, Yoongi’s eyes narrowed a bit before he shivered again, spurring Tae into action.  “Okay, time to get out.  Can you stand?”

          “I’ll try,” Yoongi sighed, but Tae still put his hand on his back and held out his other one for Yoongi to take.  The tub thankfully had an anti-slip mat in it, so Yoongi was able to get his footing a little before standing up, Tae standing with him to help him.  Moving to take both of his hands, Tae stepped back a bit as Yoongi lifted one foot and then the other.  The man let out a gruff laugh which made Tae raise his eyebrows at him once he was out of the bathtub.

          “Feel like an old man,” Yoongi mumbled.

          “You are pretty old.  Put your hands on the counter,” Tae instructed him, not waiting for any comeback or denial.  Moving around behind him, Tae put his hands on Yoongi’s still wet hips as he did so the man knew where he was, only letting go of him to open the cabinet above the toilet to pull a towel out.  He attributed the shudder that he felt run through Yoongi’s body when his hands brushed against him to the cold, so he hurried to wrap the towel around the man’s shoulders.

          “Can you get dressed, or do you want my help?”

          “’m not a child,” Yoongi grumbled, and Tae ducked his head behind the man’s back so he couldn’t see him smiling at him in the mirror.  He must be feeling a little better if he was being stubborn.

          “I know that, but that’s not what I was asking, so don’t speak like a child and tell me if you want my help or not,” Tae said. When Yoongi didn’t respond, he lifted his head curiously to look at the man’s face in the mirror.  His brow was a little furrowed, and he looked very confused. Cocking his head again, Tae raised his eyebrows inquisitively.  Pulling the towel around him, Yoongi shook his head a little and clamped his mouth shut, avoiding Tae’s gaze.

          “Okay,” Tae said slowly, stepping away from Yoongi even though he kept an eye on him as he did so, noticing the way his shoulders were slumped.  “I’m going to go check on the boys, then.  If I hear any alarming noises, I’m going to come back even if your pants aren’t on or something.  So hurry up. But go slowly.  Don’t bend down if you’re really dizzy.  Are you dizzy?”

          “No, Tae, I’m okay,” Yoongi muttered even though Tae knew he wasn’t.  Humming, unconvinced, Tae patted his shoulder on top of the towel a couple of times before heading out, his ears perked for any sounds of distress.  He didn’t close the door all the way, either, but left it a little ajar as he hurried back to the living room.

          The boys had not been idle, though Jimin had been right.  They couldn’t quite reach the blankets in Yoongi’s closet, but they had been constructing a way to get to them with the boxes they found.

          “Oh, whoa, hold on, no, nope, wait,” Tae almost squeaked, rushing with his hands out even as Jimin was climbing up on a flimsy looking cardboard box.  Frowning fiercely at him, Jimin huffed but climbed down, looking utterly defeated again.

          “I told you I can’t reach them,” he said as if it was all Tae’s fault he was only four and so short.

          “It’s okay, it’s okay,” Tae reassured him, reaching easily up and grabbing a bundle of blankets from the top shelf.  “We can start with this, and I’ll run and grab some more from my place.  Can you two set these up on the floor while I go do that really quick?”  Nodding enthusiastically, Jimin and Jungkook took the blankets from him, both of them a little overburdened; while not heavy, the blankets were large, and they walked a little like pregnant ladies toward the bed, only stopping when they bumped into it.  Chuckling quietly, Tae half-jogged out the door and to his place.  He was struck by how messy his apartment was in comparison to Yoongi’s, but he only took the time to grab his phone charger and tooth brush along with a stray blanket and as many pillows as he could hold. Jin once told him he had a pillow problem, but Tae only thought he had a pillow paradise.

          The door still wasn’t locked when he got back, but Yoongi had appeared from the bathroom.  He was leaned on the wall in the hallway, looking winded and still sickly pale, but there was a small smile on his face.  It slipped when his eyes left the boys and landed on Tae, but Tae didn’t take it personally.  He knew, by this point, that he was meddling.  Yoongi could rightfully tell him to fuck off anytime, and he would go.  

          Though he was used to other people leaving before he did, he knew he should respect Yoongi’s boundaries.  It’s why he dropped the blankets and pillows he was carrying on top of Jimin and Jungkook’s heads, their giggles muffled as they fought their way out before he turned to Yoongi.

          “Come on, old man,” he joked, holding out an arm like he was about to escort a debutant to a ball, “let’s get you to bed.” Yoongi rolled his eyes but lifted off of the wall and let Tae maneuver his forearm on top of his.  Wrapping his fingers around his for more stability, Tae shuffled slowly toward Yoongi’s bed, steering him clear of the growing pile of fabric on the floor.

          “Yoo-yoo,” Jimin said once he was free from the blankets and noticed his uncle.

          “Hold on,” Tae warned, holding them back with his hand until Yoongi could sit down on the edge of the bed.  He started to pull his arm and then his hand away, but Yoongi’s fingers seemed stuck to his.  Between his. Yoongi was looking down at their joint hands, and Tae looked down, too, stilling himself instead of just whipping his arm away.  Even though his arm was a bit twisted and he had to move to Yoongi’s side instead of standing in front of him to accommodate the man, Tae didn’t mind.  Because he was seeing something in Yoongi, some side of him he hadn’t before, and for the second time that day he couldn’t help but look at the man.  Look at how thin his fingers were, how pronounced his collarbones were, how pale and soft his skin was, how his mint green hair fell into his eyes and brushed against his long eyelashes.  

          He was undeniably incredibly handsome, and Tae felt his fingers twitch in his own before Yoongi withdrew his hand, letting it fall lamely onto his thigh as he mumbled something.  Another group of blotches appeared on his skin, and Tae realized the man was blushing. He tried to draw his own hand back slowly, his palm still warm from where Yoongi’s fingers had held on tightly, as he continued to look at the man.  A small person brushing past him finally distracted him, though, and he took an awkward step back as Jimin and Jungkook clung to their uncle’s legs, staring up at him with frowns.

          “Yoo-yoo, are you okay?” Jimin said.

          “I’ll be fine,” Yoongi grimaced, forcing a smile that Tae saw right through.

          “Tae-tae’s gonna stay with us, okay?” Jimin continued, suddenly sounding like he was the adult in the room.

          “Jimin, we can’t make—”

          “No, he said, he said.  Right, Tae-tae?” Jimin said, looking up with wide, pleading eyes and a pout that rivaled the cutest puppies Tae had ever seen, and Tae had seen a lot of sickeningly cute puppies.

          “I-I did offer.  I mean, if it’s okay with your uncle.  I-I don’t want to intrude.”  Yoongi opened his mouth as he frowned up at Tae, but he seemed to decide against whatever he was going to say.

          “If you get sick, don’t blame me,” Yoongi sighed, patting Jungkook’s head before lying down on his side.  Jungkook started to climb up onto the mattress with him, but Tae finally stepped forward to pick the boy up, swinging him around a few times before placing him on a pillow on the ground.

          “Your uncle needs the bed himself tonight, okay? We’re going to make a bed on the floor.”

          “Can we make a tent?” Jimin suggested, leaning on the mattress still as he watched Yoongi close his eyes.

          “A tent?”

          “A fort.”

          “I bet we can, as long as we’re quiet so Yoongi can sleep,” Tae said, tapping his chin as if in deep thought.

          “Yoo-yoo,” Jungkook corrected him.

          “Oh, right.  Yoo-yoo,” Tae winked at the little boy who shot him a shy grin back before stuffing his face into Bun-bun and rolling off the pillow he was on into the pile of blankets.  “I’m going to order food, too, for dinner.  Is that okay, Yoo-yoo?”  He couldn’t help the teasing tone in his voice, but when he grinned down at Yoongi, the man didn’t respond, his mouth already slightly open and his breath heavy.

          “Ah,” Tae whispered, putting a finger to his lips to Jimin and Jungkook.  They both copied the action, and Jungkook seemed to find it hilarious as he broke into a peel of laughter before clamping a hand over his mouth, his eyes wide in shock. Snorting, Tae reached past Yoongi to pull the covers over him.  Unable to resist, he placed his hand on the man’s forehead one more time.  He was still abnormally warm, but when he hummed and pushed his head a little forward into Tae’s palm, Tae couldn’t help but run his fingers through his hair a few times as his breathing evened out.

          “Good night, Yoo-yoo,” he whispered, smiling at how beautiful Yoongi looked while he slept.  If he didn’t have to attend to the children behind him, he would have loved to keep looking at Yoongi for hours, determined to see every side, every part, every frown, every smile that the man could offer.

           Fever dreams, in a word, are weird.  If Yoongi didn’t already know he was sick, the dreams would have been a giant neon flashing sign indicating how his brain was slowly being melted.  

           The dreams that made no sense were alarming.  The ones where he couldn’t identify anyone’s face because they kept ballooning up before shrinking down, their eyes melting and mouths twisting like some Picasso painting left out in the rain.  The ones that kept restarting like some saved video game as he ran down a mountain away from ninjas on bicycles and then from bears who chased him to the top of a roof he tried to jump off and then from what looked like ninja bears who finally made him wake up in a cold sweat.  The ones he couldn’t remember but he knew felt so real they were so vivid in the middle of them that he didn’t know he was dreaming but ended up being black holes, leaving him with nothing but a sense of unease when he woke. These dreams, the one a therapist might want to analyze in excruciating detail, made no sense, but their tone was the same.  Despair and survival and fear pervaded through them all.

           The dreams of his neighbor were confusing, because Yoongi didn’t often recognize the people in his dreams.  He wasn’t used to his dreams recurring, either, but it seemed like every time he slipped into sleep, Tae was there.  He was an outside observer the first time, like a hovering camera attached to a drone. Tae was riding on, of all things, an elephant.  The figure on top of the giant animal was so obviously Tae.  He was too tan to be anyone else, and his smile, a big, boxy, goofy smile so proud like he had just tamed this wild beast and claimed it as his own, was so obviously Tae.  Still, the image was so bizarre that Yoongi’s mind tried to change the channel.

           The next time he saw Tae, he was sitting in a coffee shop.  The setting soothed his mind, and since he was aware he was dreaming, he allowed himself to settle into this dream.  He could almost hear the soft jazz playing through the speakers.  He could almost hear the hiss of the espresso machine and the calling of names and clacking of computer keyboards and humming of someone sitting next to him.  For some reason, it was Sunmi.  And while part of his brain questioned her appearance immediately, dream Yoongi was completely at ease.  It made sense in Yoongi’s consciousness, he rationalized later.  He had always felt comfortable around Sunmi.  They had been friends first, and most of their communication had been in the form of sarcasm and teasing.  Even when they broke up, it was completely amenable. Nothing had been wrong in their relationship, but they both realized they had gotten and stayed together more for comfortability than compatibility.  They had sat in many a coffee shop almost daily when they dated, so Yoongi almost thought he was dreaming a memory.  She was as gorgeous as the last time he had seen her, her cheekbones high and lips painted a vibrant red, her favorite shade.  She didn’t look up from her phone or her book once, but even that didn’t bother Yoongi.  It was comfortable, and it was the first pleasant dream he could recall having since he had gotten sick.

           But then some commotion caught his attention, instantly shattering any pretense that this was a memory.  The shouting and yelling was almost comical, like he was watching some bad drama, but the sound of a slap was what made him rise.  He felt see-through, though, like he didn’t have legs.  He couldn’t see his own hands, even, but he was moving across the shop that soon dissolved into a dumpster, no, a trash pile, no, an entire dump. Trash looming all around him, boxes and stacks of trash, bags and stray items, discarded food and broken toys, clothes with holes and books with mold.  He wanted to stop, to turn around, to run away from all of that, or stay and clean it, but he heard another smack, clearly someone’s skin hitting another, so he stumbled over and pushed through the waste in front of him until it disappeared.

          His neighbor was sitting in the corner holding his hand to his cheek, and some nameless and faceless entity was standing over him, more of a black, formless shape than man, though its voice was rough and jeering and biting as it shouted, so Yoongi, who, once he got past his anger stage, couldn’t imagine ever hitting anyone for any reason, rushed forward to push the man, the thing, out of the way, except the moment he lunged at it, it disappeared.  He stumbled over his own feet, then, and fell onto his knees, staring at the hands that had appeared.  He became fascinated by them because they weren’t his hands.  They couldn’t be; there was no tattoo on his arms, and he had this one vein that always stuck out, protruding a little, on his left hand.  

          These hands weren’t his, but he recognized them. He made a fist and twisted them around, looking at the back of them.  At the back of his brother’s hands.  When he heard a whimper in the corner, his eyes finally snapped up, but Tae was gone. Jimin was huddled there instead, his puffy cheeks red and wet with tears as he shook, and Jungkook stood in front of him, his arms out and his feet spread wide as if to shield his brother from view. 

             When Yoongi—his brother? his brother’s hands—reached toward him, though, the boy actually growled and bore his teeth, no small rabbit teeth turning into sharp razor fangs, the hands recoiled immediately, so quickly that Yoongi felt himself stumble backwards, falling back, back, back, until he fell out of the dream completely and onto his bed so quickly the air got knocked out of him, and he sat up, gasping for breath.

          “Yoongi?” a deep and sleep addled voice mumbled, and Yoongi clamped his eyes shut to stop the world from spinning, to stop anything from spilling out of him.

          “Yoongi?  Breathe, Yoongi,” the voice said, and he did, harshly, the release so painful he felt like he had been punched.  

          “You’re okay.”  The voice had a body.  It was real, and warm, and its hand was rubbing Yoongi’s back as he hunched over, putting his head between his knees and clenching his fingers around his shins.

          “There we go.  In and out.  Did you have a nightmare?”  Nodding gently, Yoongi heard the voice sigh in sympathy.

          “Do you want to tell me about it?”  He did.  He wanted to tell him how afraid he was.  How much he felt like he was messing up.  How easily and quickly dreams could become reality and reality could merge into dreams.  But he shook his head, instead.  “Okay, that’s okay.  Do you want some water?”

          “Jun-Junki,” Yoongi shuddered, trying to fold into himself more and more.  “I dreamed you—you died.  You left me, and, and—”

          “Oh, Yoongi,” the voice said slowly, the hand stilling on his back.  Another shudder, and the hand started to move away.  “Okay, let’s lay you back down.  Can you do that—”

          “Please,” Yoongi pleaded, fumbling to grab onto something and falling into the voice’s chest.  It, he, was so warm, warm and welcoming, and Yoongi wanted to stay there forever. “Please don’t leave me again.  I-I can’t.”

          “O-okay,” the voice said uneasily.  “Okay, I-I’m here.  Just-just lie down, again?  Here we go.”

          Yoongi let himself be guided, led, moved because it’s what he needed.  He needed just one good dream, just one comforting thought.  He needed the hand brushing through his hair and the arm holding him close.  He needed the chest to sob into, the warm skin to welcome him back even after he had been away for so long.  He needed that voice to tell him he was going to be alright, that they were going to be alright, that everything was going to be alright.

          “Okay, okay,” it said, which was almost good enough. It almost sounded like him.  It was almost too good.  It was the best fever dream he could remember having, and even if he knew it was a dream, the acknowledgement only made him calmer and more relaxed like he actually believed everything was going to be alright.

A/N: AH!!!

I always have to have someone sick in a bathtub in my stories, apparently.

What’s up with those dreams???  Dang.
trail.content_abstract:
Summary:  Yoongi loves photography. Taehyung loves photography. Yoongi likes eating good food and dogs and holding hands. Taehyung likes holding hands and dogs and eating good food.  Yoongi does not, dear God, like kids.  Taehyung, thank God, loves kids. But when his brother dies, it’s Yoongi who suddenly has to look after four-year-old Jimin and three-year-old Jungkook.

A/N:  You guessed it!  It’s trope time!

The Korean version of 911 (I’m in the U.S.) is 119. It’s backwards!  That’s easy to remember.  (There’s also 116, apparently).

The italics in this story are past conversations or thoughts.

More notes at the end.

WC: 6,803

Warnings: Some bad words. People throwing up, ew.  Reference of abuse / physical violence.

Masterlist

13. Hoseok and Jimin “Made Out”

14. Fever Dreams

           Yoongi was, honestly, impressed and surprised and a little bit proud of himself for making it so long before it happened.  He’s always been introverted, so to have gone from living alone and having every minute to himself if he so wished to suddenly never being alone even when he was just trying to go to the bathroom was a difficult whirlwind to adjust to.
